seqEasyFunctions 0.1.0
  • Reference

    Generate a list of ggplot2 heatmaps from a list of matrices.

    plotggplotHeatmap.Rd

    This function takes a list of matrices (typically the output of matList) and generates a list of ggplot2 heatmaps, with options for color palettes, scaling, labels, average profiles, k-means clustering, log2 transformation, dotted lines, and row splitting.

    plotggplotHeatmap(
  matl,
  color_palette = "red_white",
  zMin = NULL,
  zMax = NULL,
  xlab = NULL,
  ylab = NULL,
  fill_label = "Signal",
  title = NULL,
  wins,
  break_labels,
  average_profile = FALSE,
  k_clusters = NULL,
  log2 = FALSE,
  dottedlines = FALSE,
  split = NULL
)

    Arguments

    matl

    A named list of matrices, where each matrix represents signal intensity over genomic regions (e.g., output of matList).

    color_palette

    A character string specifying the color palette to use (e.g., "red_white", "viridis", "magma", "inferno", "cividis", "Blues", "Greens", "Reds", "RdBu", "RdYlBu", "PuOr", "BrBG"). Alternatively, a vector of colors for a custom palette can be provided.

    zMin

    A numeric value specifying the minimum value for the color scale. If "auto", it will be set to the 1st percentile of all values in matl. If NULL, no lower limit is enforced by the function (ggplot2 will determine it).

    zMax

    A numeric value specifying the maximum value for the color scale. If "auto", it will be set to the 99th percentile of all values in matl. If NULL, no upper limit is enforced by the function (ggplot2 will determine it).

    xlab

    A character string specifying the label for the x-axis.

    ylab

    A character string specifying the label for the y-axis.

    fill_label

    A character string specifying the label for the fill scale (legend).

    title

    An optional character string specifying the title for the plot (will be used if average_profile = FALSE).

    wins

    A named integer vector specifying the number of bins (windows) that the matrices in matl were normalized to for each feature type. The names should correspond to the feature types (e.g., c("Gene" = 10)).

    break_labels

    A character vector specifying the labels for the breaks on the x-axis. The length of this vector must be equal to the number of breaks defined by wins plus one (for the start).

    average_profile

    A logical value indicating whether to include an average profile plot above each heatmap.

    k_clusters

    An optional integer specifying the number of clusters for k-means clustering of the rows in each matrix. If provided, the heatmap will be faceted by cluster.

    log2

    A logical value indicating whether to apply a log2 transformation (with a pseudocount of 1) to the matrices in matl before plotting.

    dottedlines

    A logical value indicating whether to add dotted vertical lines at the breaks defined by wins.

    split

    An optional data.frame used to split the rows of the heatmaps. It should have one column, and its rownames should correspond to the rownames of the matrices in matl (assumed to be gene IDs).

    Value

    A single ggplot2 object if only one matrix is provided in matl, otherwise a combined ggplot2 object using patchwork.

    Examples

    # Assuming you have generated a list of matrices using matList()
if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Create a dummy matrix list for demonstration
mat_list <- list(
  sample1 = matrix(rnorm(100), nrow = 20, dimnames = list(paste0("gene", 1:20))),
  sample2 = matrix(rnorm(100), nrow = 20, dimnames = list(paste0("gene", 1:20)))
)
wins_info <- c("FeatureA" = 5)
break_labs <- c("Start", "FeatureA")

# Basic heatmap
plotggplotHeatmap(matl = mat_list, wins = wins_info, break_labels = break_labs)

# Heatmap with average profile
plotggplotHeatmap(matl = mat_list, wins = wins_info, break_labels = break_labs,
                  average_profile = TRUE)

# Heatmap with k-means clustering
plotggplotHeatmap(matl = mat_list, wins = wins_info, break_labels = break_labs,
                  k_clusters = 2)

# Heatmap with row splitting
split_df <- data.frame(group = factor(rep(c("Group1", "Group2"), each = 10)),
                       row.names = paste0("gene", 1:20))
plotggplotHeatmap(matl = mat_list, wins = wins_info, break_labels = break_labs,
                  split = split_df)
} # }
